column4: why doesnt sound work, is there a firewall, how do I get xmms, why doesnt mplayer play .wmvs, how do I get kde, which wm is the best?
there have I got your attention?
SMB connection failed
possible that storage is owned by root? ls -ld /mnt/storage
drwxr-xr-x  2 root root 48 2005-05-16 04:23 /mnt/storage/
it is owned by root, is that a prob?
that's it. change is to the user
Ill try it, but isnt that what uid=1000 is for? and why would it work using 'mount' if that was a problem?
because you used sudo
well its the exact same problem Im afraid
looks like it didnt make a difference
while just reading using fstab means mount is run by the user which has no access to the dir
not to mention that the other share, which is on another server //10.10.1.20/Data /mnt/PubStore works fine with fstab, and its owned by root
but I run it with sudo, of course I have access Im running as root
have you changed it?
yes
but still no difference, why would it say "Access Denied" if it was a problem with the mount point ffs?
access denied in my interpretation is that you don't have access to the target dir
no the error comes from smbmount
its as if the password is wrong, but the same username and password works fine if I mount it using 'mount -t smbfs -o blablabla'
possible also that you have to enable encryption in the smb.conf because pain text passed may not work. this is one bug in the latest tiger of OS X.

tell me this: why would it work doing it with mount -t smbfs -o blablabla, but not when I mount it with the same options specified in /etc/fstab?? how could plain text passwords possibly be a problem from /etc/fstab but not doing it directly??
so it must be with the fstab then. i think you have to check access ownership of the dir...
its NOT ownership of the dir
